repnme.cdata!:
Bulgaria - Making a difference in an
            European Union member state

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            Bulgaria’s economy. Bulgaria has come a long way from its
            difficult early years of transition to a market economy.
            Country’s’ main challenges were to mitigate the negative
            impact of the global economic crisis, to enhance
            productivity, and to strengthen public institutions and
            governance to accelerate convergence of living standards to
            average European Union countries. The Revenue Administration
            and Reform Project supported the integration of tax and
            social contribution revenue collection, to improve the
            effectiveness and efficiency of the public revenue
            collection system in Bulgaria and facilitate private sector
            development. The Social Investment and Employment Promotion
            Project brought school improvements, energy efficiency,
            water supply and sewerage to small villages, and enabled
            rehabilitation of homes for the elderly and for children
            without parental care. The Registration and Cadastre Project
            contributed to a secure and efficient real estate market.
            Bulgaria continued to make great strides in improving
            financial management and channeling increased revenue to
            programs that were delivering improved water connections,
            better schools, and renovated homes for the elderly.

Nivel de vida mejora en Bulgaria por su
            ingreso a la Unión Europea

This Results Profile focuses on
            Bulgaria’s economy. Bulgaria has come a long way from its

            Country’s’ main challenges were to mitigate the negative
            impact of the global economic crisis, to enhance
            productivity, and to strengthen public institutions and
            governance to accelerate convergence of living standards to

            water supply and sewerage to small villages, and enabled
            rehabilitation of homes for the elderly and for children
            without parental care. The Registration and Cadastre Project
            contributed to a secure and efficient real estate market.
            Bulgaria continued to make great strides in improving
            financial management and channeling increased revenue to

            better schools, and renovated homes for the elderly.

repnme.cdata!:
Bulgaria case : making a difference in an
            EU member state

abstracts.cdata!:
Bulgaria's efforts to transition to
            a market economy were rewarded by membership in the European
            Union (EU) in 2007 but the country still faced steep
            challenges to elevate the income of its more than seven
            million people to the average seen in the EU. Partnering
            with International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
            (IBRD), Bulgaria continues to make great strides in
            improving financial management, channeling increased revenue
            to programs that are delivering new or improved water
            connections, better schools, and renovated homes for the elderly.

docna.cdata!:
Bulgaria case : making a difference in an EU
            member state

display_title.display_title:
Bulgaria case : making a
            difference in an EU member state

abstracts.cdata!:
The Revenue Administration Reform
            Project for Bulgaria had a satisfactory outcome and moderate
            risk to development outcome. Both the Bank and the borrower
            performances were highly satisfactory. The main lessons
            learned were: 1. Early confidence building is crucial. With
            the transfer of collection responsibility to the revenue
            administration, the social security agency loses control
            over its revenue generation. 2. Integration is a process
            which involves a multitude of stakeholders. It is important
            to involve these stakeholders actively in the design and
            monitoring and active management of the reform process. 3.
            It is important that strong performance standards are set in
            relation to collection performance for both tax and social
            contributions and early measures taken to collect and
            analyze performance data. 4. Transferring the collection
            responsibility for local taxes to municipalities is a
            crucial precondition for achieving substantial efficiency
            gains in national tax revenue collection. 5. Continuity in
            the leadership of the tax agency provides an important
            contribution to successful implementation of the reform
            process. 6. Tax administration reform and integrating the
            collection responsibility for social contributions is a
            multi-year process. A medium to long-term strategic vision,
            owned by the implementing agency, is a prerequisite for the
            successful completion and sustainability of the reform
            process. 7. Business process re-engineering and related
            automated applications must be fully integrated throughout
            the tax administration, with appropriate management of the
            organizational transition  including human resource and
            training aspect  as a central part of the process. 8.
            Moving to an e-tax system is an essential process for
            reducing the compliance and administrative burden and the
            risk of corruption. Increasing the use of electronic tools,
            in particular e-filing, by taxpayers therefore is important.
            This requires, in addition to providing incentives for
            e-filing, to eliminate obstacles and create the necessary
            legal framework for the use of e-tax. 9. Tax administration
            reform frequently requires changes in the legal framework.
            These changes must be initiated as early as possible in
            order to ensure a clear and sufficient legal basis for the
            reform. 10. Need for setting realistic, measurable
            performance targets and avoiding construction
            works/renovations which often contribute to delays in
            institutional development projects.
